posts.creator: Joffrey Bion
posts.title: Amper Update, November 2025 ‚Äì Extensibility Preview
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Amper 0.9.0 is out, and it brings the first version of our extensibility prototype! Read on for all of the details, and see the release notes for the full list of changes and bug fixes.
To get support for Amper‚Äôs latest features, use IntelliJ IDEA 2025.3 Beta (or newer).
New Amper website
We revamped our documentation and turned it into a brand new website! You no longer have to read Markdown files on GitHub. We hope you‚Äôll enjoy the new structure, as well as the navigation and search functionality.
Check it out at https://amper.org.




Extensibility preview
It‚Äôs finally here: our first preview of Amper‚Äôs extensibility!
Our philosophy is to give a ‚Äúbatteries included‚Äù experience to our users, and this is why we want Amper to cover the most common use cases out of the box. However, a lot of projects have special needs, and the built-in behavior falls short eventually. To address this, Amper now offers the option to write custom tasks and expose them to your modules via plugins.
Note: Only local plugins are supported at the moment, but we will soon add the ability to publish and share plugins.
In Amper 0.9.0, you can create modules with the new jvm/amper-plugin product type. These modules contain the Kotlin code implementing your custom tasks, and a plugin.yaml file to register your tasks and their inputs and outputs.
Why do you need to use both Kotlin and YAML? As usual with Amper, tooling is paramount. Thanks to this approach, you will get nice diagnostics in case you make mistakes with your task wiring. Don‚Äôt worry, though, navigating between YAML and Kotlin is already seamless with the current basic IDE support.




Task dependencies are automatically inferred based on inputs and outputs, and task avoidance is already available by default. Inputs can be simple scalar values or files, or even your module‚Äôs compile or runtime classpath ‚Äì thanks to the built-in Classpath type. Outputs can be regular files, but they can also be registered as generated sources or resources so the rest of the build takes them into account.
Build your own plugin from scratch by following our plugin quick-start guide, and tell us what you think in our Slack channel or in a YouTrack issue.
Please bear in mind that this preview is incomplete, and many more features will come in the future, including:
The ability to publish plugins and share them with other projects.
Templates that are bundled with your plugin to add configuration to the consumer module.
Reduced boilerplate when writing tasks that are only used in a single module.
Services and libraries for common task-authoring needs.
More IDE quick-fixes and intention actions.




Learn more about the current and future state in our plugin documentation.
Dependency resolution performance improvements
The dependency resolution phase was previously a performance bottleneck, especially during IDE import and sync.
Even though all downloaded files are locally cached and reused, building the dependency graph itself takes time, as Amper needs to read all the local pom.xml and Gradle metadata files. Amper now caches the dependency graph itself and reuses it when your dependencies haven‚Äôt changed, which can sometimes save tens of seconds on hot caches!
There is certainly more we can do here, and we‚Äôll continue improving dependency resolution performance, so stay tuned!
Incremental compilation for Java
Amper has had task avoidance since day one, which means that it skips the whole compilation task of a module if its sources and dependencies haven‚Äôt changed. However, this doesn‚Äôt help if you have a large module with lots of sources, because any change in any file will cause the recompilation of the whole module.
This is where incremental compilation comes in. In Amper 0.9.0, you can use our incremental Java compilation engine, which recompiles only what‚Äôs necessary based on the exact changes in the module sources. Any change in your sources will still cause the compilation task to run, but now the task itself will be faster.
To enable this feature, simply add the following to your module.yaml file:
settings:
  java:
    compileIncrementally: true
Maven-like layout support
Amper‚Äôs default directory layout is simple and concise, and we love it. That said, we do understand that transitioning from Maven or Gradle is quite tedious and error-prone if it involves moving all files around. This is particularly painful if you want to try out Amper in a separate long-lived Git branch and get updates from your main branch.
As of Amper 0.9.0, you can choose to keep your sources and resources in the conventional Maven directory layout, so you don‚Äôt have to move your existing files immediately:

To do so, add layout: maven-like to your module.yaml file. If you intend to do this for all your modules, use a template to handle this in a central place.
Note: The maven-like layout is only available for the ‚Äújvm/app‚Äù and ‚Äújvm/lib‚Äù product types.
Library catalog at the project root
Amper now supports placing your Gradle-style version catalog (libs.versions.toml) in the project root instead of in the gradle folder. Of course, you are free to keep using gradle/libs.versions.toml if you want to keep compatibility with your Gradle layout.
In the IDE, using intention actions to extract dependencies to a new catalog will now create the catalog in the project root.
Note: You can only use a single library catalog for your project, so you have to pick one of the locations.
IDE improvements
Auto-sync of the project configuration
Changes to your Amper configuration files are now automatically taken into account, which means you no longer need to manually click the Sync  button!
This was made possible by the improvements in dependency resolution caching we‚Äôve seen above.
If syncing involves downloading new dependencies or other lengthy processes, you‚Äôll see a progress indicator in the status bar; otherwise, the sync should be seamless.



                    
Note: This behavior can be configured for the current project in ‚ÄúSettings | Build, Execution, Deployment | Build Tools‚Äù. If you want to change the default for future new projects, you can do so in ‚ÄúSettings | Advanced Settings | Build Tools. Amper‚Äù.
Sync details
The Build tool window now provides more insights into the stages of the sync process, and shows errors and warnings arising from them.


IDE assistance for setting the main class
You can configure the entrypoint of a jvm/app module using settings.jvm.mainClass. Finding the fully-qualified name of your main class is never fun, though. This is why IntelliJ IDEA now provides completion for it directly in your YAML file!
The completion list includes all class names that have a valid main function. By default, only classes present in the module itself are shown, but you can also invoke completion a second time to get results from your dependencies too:




That‚Äôs not all. IntelliJ IDEA also provides assistance with navigation and resolution, and it will even warn you about the infamous missing Kt suffix when referring to the class Kotlin generates for top-level main functions.

Improved quick-fix for overridden catalog versions
Amper warns you when your module doesn‚Äôt get the requested version of a dependency because of dependency conflicts. However, when this happens with a library catalog dependency, it isn‚Äôt obvious what the fix should be, as it depends on your intent.
To address this issue, IntelliJ IDEA now offers two different quick-fixes: one to replace the catalog reference with an explicit version in the problematic module, and one to update the version in the catalog itself. Use Alt+Enter or click the More actions‚Ä¶ option in the warning tooltip to access these fixes:





Dedicated color theme settings
You can now customize the colors in your Amper YAML files.
Head over to File | Settings | Editor | Color Scheme | Amper and get creative!

Updated default versions
We updated some of our default versions for toolchains and frameworks:
Kotlin 2.2.21
Compose Hot Reload 1.0.0-rc01
KSP 2.3.0
JUnit Platform 6.0.1




Also, the default value for settings.jvm.release is now 21.
Try Amper 0.9.0
To update an existing project, use the ./amper update command.
To get started with Amper, check out our Getting started guide. Take a look at some examples, follow a tutorial, or read the comprehensive user guide depending on your learning style.
Try Amper
                                                    
Share your feedback
Amper is still experimental and under active development. You can provide feedback about your experience by joining the discussion in the Kotlinlang Slack‚Äôs #amper channel or sharing your suggestions and ideas in a YouTrack issue. Your input and use cases help shape the future of Amper!

posts.creator: Alyona Chernyaeva
posts.title: Scaling Kotlin Adoption Across Your Organization
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
Guest post by Urs Peter, Senior Software Engineer and JetBrains-certified Kotlin Trainer. For readers who‚Äôd like a more structured way to build Kotlin skills, Urs also leads the¬†Kotlin Upskill Program at Xebia Academy.
This is the fifth post in The Ultimate Guide to Successfully Adopting Kotlin in a Java-Dominated Environment, a series that follows how Kotlin adoption grows among real teams, from a single developer‚Äôs curiosity to company-wide transformation.
All parts in the series:
Getting Started With Kotlin for Java Developers
Evaluating Kotlin in Real Projects
Growing Kotlin Adoption in Your Company
Helping Decision-Makers Say Yes to Kotlin
Scaling Kotlin Adoption Across Your Organization
Success Factors for Large-Scale Kotlin Adoption
Gaining developer buy-in and management support for Kotlin is a significant milestone, but it‚Äôs not the finish line. The real challenge begins when you‚Äôre faced with existing Java codebases that need to coexist with or transition to Kotlin. How do you navigate this hybrid world effectively?
The key to managing legacy codebases is developing a strategy that aligns with your organizational goals and operational realities. Here‚Äôs a proven approach that has worked out well in practice.
Application lifecycle strategy
Different applications require different approaches based on their lifecycle phase. Let‚Äôs examine three distinct categories:
End-of-life applications
Strategy: Leave them alone.
If an application is scheduled for retirement, there‚Äôs no business case for migration. Keep these systems in Java and focus your energy where it matters most. The cost of migration will never be justified by the remaining lifespan of the application.
New systems
Strategy: Default to Kotlin.
In organizations where Kotlin adoption is complete, greenfield projects naturally start with Kotlin. If the adoption process is in progress, teams often get the choice between Java and Kotlin. Choose wisely ;-).
Active applications
Strategy: Pragmatic, feature-driven migration.
Active applications are the ones that require careful consideration: Rewriting for the sake of rewriting is a tough sell to your Product Owner. Instead, combine migration efforts with new feature development. This approach provides tangible business value while modernizing your codebase. The different attack angles we already discussed in the section: Extend/Convert an existing Java application.
Java-to-Kotlin conversion approaches
When converting Java to Kotlin, you have several options, each with distinct trade-offs:
1. Complete rewrite
Best for: Small codebases¬†
Challenge: Time-intensive for larger systems
Rewriting a codebase from scratch gives you the cleanest, most idiomatic Kotlin code. This approach is suitable for small codebases, like a MicroService. For large codebases, this approach generally tends to be prohibitively expensive.
2. IDE auto-conversion with manual refinement
Best for: Medium codebases with dedicated refactoring time
Challenge: Manual refinements are mandatory¬†
IntelliJ IDEA‚Äôs Convert Java to Kotlin feature provides a literal translation that‚Äôs far from idiomatic. Consider this example:
Take 1:¬†
Java
record Developer(
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†String name,
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†List<String> languages
) {}
Raw auto-conversion result:
Kotlin
@JvmRecord
data class Developer(
¬†¬†¬†val name: String?,
¬†¬†¬†val languages: MutableList<String?>?
)
This conversion has several issues:
Everything becomes nullable (overly defensive).
Java Collections become Kotlin‚Äôs MutableList instead of¬† Kotlin‚Äôs default read-only List.
Improving the conversion with jspecify annotations:
Luckily, for the conversion of all Java types to Nullable types in Kotlin, there is a remedy in the form of @NonNull/@Nullable annotations. Different options are available; the most modern one is jspecify, which has recently also been officially supported by Spring:
<dependency>
¬†¬†¬†<groupId>org.jspecify</groupId>
¬†¬†¬†<artifactId>jspecify</artifactId>
¬†¬†¬†<version>1.0.0</version>
</dependency>

implementation("org.jspecify:jspecify:1.0.0")
With jspecify, we can annotate the Java code with @Nullable and @NonNull.
Take 2:¬†
Java
import org.jspecify.annotations.NonNull;
import org.jspecify.annotations.Nullable;

record Developer(
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†@NonNull String name,¬†
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†@NonNull List<@NonNull String> languages,
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†@Nullable String email
) {}
Now the auto-conversion produces much better results:
Kotlin
@JvmRecord
data class Developer(
¬†¬†¬†//üòÉ non-null as requested
¬†¬†¬†val name: String,¬†
¬†¬†¬†//üòÉ both, collection and type are non-null
¬† val languages: MutableList<String>,
¬†¬†¬†//üòÉ nullable as requested
¬† val email: String?,¬†
)
Limitations of the auto conversion approach:
Even with jspecify annotations, complex Java patterns don‚Äôt translate well. Consider this auto-converted code example shown in section: 3. No more checked Exceptions, yet safer code in Kotlin:
Kotlin
fun downloadAndGetLargestFile(urls: MutableList<String>): String? {
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†//ü§® using Stream, instead of Kotlin Collections
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†val contents = urls.stream().map { urlStr: String? ->
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†//ü§® still using Optional, rather than Nullable types
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†//ü§® var but we want val!
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†var optional: Optional<URL>
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†//ü§® useless try-catch, no need to catch in Kotlin
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†try {
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†optional = Optional.of(URI(urlStr).toURL())
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†} catch (e: URISyntaxException) {
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†optional = Optional.empty<URL>()
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†} catch (e: MalformedURLException) {
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†optional = Optional.empty<URL>()
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†}
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†optional
¬†¬†¬†}.filter { it!!.isPresent() }//ü§® discouraged !! to force conversion to non-null
¬†¬†¬†¬†.map {it.get() }
¬†¬†¬†¬†.map { url: URL ->
      //ü§® useless try-catch, no need to catch in Kotlin
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†try {
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†url.openStream().use { `is` ->¬†
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†String(`is`.readAllBytes(), StandardCharsets.UTF_8)
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†}
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†} catch (e: IOException) {
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†throw IllegalArgumentException(e)
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†}
¬†¬†¬†¬†}.toList()
¬†¬†¬†//ü§® usage of Java collections‚Ä¶
¬†¬†¬†return Collections.max(contents)
}
The autoconversion is far away from the desired, idiomatic result:
Kotlin
fun downloadAndGetLargestFile(urls: List<String>): String? =
¬†¬†¬†urls.mapNotNull {
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†runCatching { URI(it).toURL() }.getOrNull()
¬†¬†¬†}.maxOfOrNull{ it.openStream().use{ it.reader().readText() } }
The auto-conversion provides a starting point, but significant manual refinement and knowledge of idiomatic Kotlin is required to achieve truly idiomatic Kotlin.
3. AI-assisted conversion
Best for: Larger codebases with robust testing infrastructure
Challenge: Manual review required
AI can potentially produce more idiomatic results than basic auto-conversion, but success requires careful preparation:
Prerequisites:
Comprehensive testing coverage: Since LLMs are unpredictable, you need reliable tests to catch AI hallucinations.
Well-crafted system prompts: Create detailed instructions for idiomatic Kotlin conversions that are aligned with your standards. You can use this system prompt as a starting point.
Extensive code review: AI output requires a thorough review for logical and idiomatic correctness, which can be mentally taxing for large codebases.
Using the proposed system prompt to guide the conversion, the result is quite satisfying, yet not perfect:
Kotlin
fun downloadAndGetLargestFile(urls: List<String>): String? {
¬†¬†¬†val contents = urls
      .mapNotNull {¬†
            urlStr -> runCatching { URI(urlStr).toURL() }.getOrNull()¬†
      }.mapNotNull { url -> runCatching {¬†
            url.openStream().use { it.readAllBytes().toString(UTF_8)
      ¬†¬†¬†}¬†
      }.getOrNull() }

¬†¬†¬†return contents.maxOrNull()
}
4. Auto-conversion at scale
Best for: Massive codebases requiring systematic transformation
Currently, there‚Äôs no official tooling for converting Java codebases to idiomatic Kotlin at scale. However, both Meta and Uber have successfully tackled this challenge for their Android codebases using approaches that work equally well for backend applications. The following documentation and talks provide insights into how Meta and Uber approach this quest:
Meta‚Äôs approach:                                                                                    
 
Strategy: Rule-based, deterministic transformation
Resources:                                                                                               

Engineering blog post
Conference talk                           
Uber‚Äôs approach:                                                                                 
 
Strategy: Rule-based, deterministic transformation using AI to generate conversion rules
Resource: KotlinConf presentation
Both companies succeeded by creating systematic, repeatable processes rather than relying on manual conversion or simple automation. Their rule-based approaches ensure consistency and quality across millions of lines of code.
Important: Converting Java to Kotlin at scale introduces a challenge on the social level: to be reliable, you still want ‚Äòthe human in the loop‚Äô reviewing the generated code. However, if not planned carefully, Engineers can easily be overwhelmed by the flood of pull requests resulting from the automated conversion. Therefore, the social impact needs to be considered carefully.¬†
Remember, successful large-scale Kotlin adoption isn‚Äôt just about converting code ‚Äì it‚Äôs about building team expertise, establishing coding standards, and creating sustainable processes that deliver long-term value to your organization.
Short recap on when to use which approach:
Small application or being rewritten anyway?
‚Üí Rewrite in Kotlin (1)

Medium codebases with dedicated refactoring time or team learning Kotlin?
‚Üí Intellij IDEA Auto-Conversion + refine (start with tests first) (2)




Mid/large code with repeated patterns and good tests?
‚Üí AI-assisted approach (3) 

Org-level migration to Kotlin across many services?
‚Üí Auto-Conversion at scale with concrete plan (platform-led) (4)
Unlock Kotlin‚Äôs full potential
Kotlin makes developers productive fast. Its concise syntax, safety features, and rich standard library help many developers write better code within weeks ‚Äì often through self-study or on-the-job learning. But without guidance, many fall into the trap of using Kotlin in a Java-like way: sticking to mutable structures, verbose patterns, and missing out on idiomatic features.
Reaching the next level
Reaching the next level ‚Äì embracing immutability, expression-oriented code, DSLs, and structured concurrency with Coroutines (with or without Virtual Threads) ‚Äì is where many developers get stuck.
At this stage, I‚Äôve found that external training makes a far greater difference than self-study. Even developers with years of Kotlin experience often benefit from focused coaching to adopt idiomatic patterns and unlock the language‚Äôs full potential.




To Kotlin or Not to Kotlin: What Kind of Company Do You Want to Be?
Ultimately, the decision to adopt Kotlin reflects your engineering culture. Do you value the:
Traditional approach (Java): Conservative, ceremonial, stable.
Progressive approach (Kotlin): Pragmatic, modern, adaptive.
Both have their merits. Java will get the job done. Kotlin will likely get it done better, with happier developers and fewer bugs. The question isn‚Äôt whether Kotlin is better ‚Äì it‚Äôs whether your organization is ready to invest in being better.
The journey from that first Kotlin test to organization-wide adoption isn‚Äôt always smooth, but with the right approach, it‚Äôs remarkably predictable. Start small, prove value, build community, and scale thoughtfully.
Your developers ‚Äì current and future ‚Äì will thank you.
Urs Peter
Urs is a seasoned software engineer, solution architect, conference speaker, and trainer with over 20 years of experience in building resilient, scalable, and mission-critical systems, mostly involving Kotlin and Scala.
Besides his job as a consultant, he is also a passionate trainer and author of a great variety of courses ranging from language courses for Kotlin and Scala to architectural trainings such as Microservices and Event-Driven Architectures.
As a people person by nature, he loves to share knowledge and inspire and get inspired by peers on meetups and conferences. Urs is a JetBrains certified Kotlin trainer.

posts.creator: Paul Chapman
posts.title: Visual Studio ‚Äì Built for the Speed of Modern Development
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
The release of Visual Studio 2026 two weeks ago marks the next evolution in Microsoft‚Äôs 50-year commitment to deliver the tools that developers love and enterprises trust, built to move at the pace of modern development. Software development is moving faster than ever, and Visual Studio is evolving right along with you.
Today, we‚Äôre announcing an important step forward in the lifecycle and release cadence for Visual Studio. Visual Studio will be a continuously updated modern IDE designed to deliver innovation as soon as it is ready, while maintaining the reliability and stability you count on every day. We‚Äôll deliver this through monthly feature updates and a new annual major release.
Why We‚Äôre Modernizing
Visual Studio now innovates at the pace of modern software. Whether you build desktop apps, cloud services, games, web APIs, or AI agents, the IDE will now ship the latest performance and capability improvements every month, with GitHub Copilot experiences always up to date.
We also heard the request for frictionless updates. Your existing projects, solutions, and extensions continue to work as they do today. We‚Äôre maintaining a high compatibility bar across monthly and annual releases, so you stay productive while the IDE evolves in place and your builds remain stable.
Because the IDE is decoupled from the build tools, these changes do not require you to modify existing projects or rebuild working applications. Visual Studio updates monthly, but your .NET or C++ compiler build tools, runtimes, and extensions continue to work exactly as before. Build tools and SDKs have their own multi-year lifecycles, so your build environment remains stable even as the IDE gets new features.
Built for Modern Development
Since Visual Studio 2017, we have been steadily increasing our release cadence, delivering quarterly feature updates, servicing releases, and flexible build tools choices. With Visual Studio 2026, we are taking the next step, moving to a modern support lifecycle that keeps you on the latest tools and features automatically.
This new approach means:
Feature updates every month, not every quarter.
A new annual version each year, released in November alongside the .NET release.
Predictable servicing and support under the Modern Support Lifecycle, with one year of monthly feature updates followed by one year of security fixes.
Update to the latest release to remain supported and serviced with new features, fixes, and security updates.
It is all about giving you updates as soon as they are ready.
Build Tools Freedom ‚Äì You Are in Control
With these changes to how Visual Studio is updated and supported, it‚Äôs equally important to understand how build tools and components fit into this new model.
We know every team moves at its own pace. Visual Studio continues to carry a wide range of build tools and components to target the platforms you‚Äôve come to expect. With multiple supported versions of these build tools included, you can choose when to move your projects forward. You can adopt the latest compiler, runtime, or SDK on your schedule while still benefiting from IDE improvements and AI features each month.
These build tools, SDKs, and runtimes are available under their own support lifecycles. For example, modern .NET releases every year, with Standard Term Support (STS) for 2 years and Long-Term Support (LTS) support for 3 years. The lifecycle for .NET Framework is tied to the Windows release in which it ships.
For C++ developers, we are also decoupling the Microsoft C++ (MSVC) compilers and Build Tools from the Visual Studio lifecycle. This lets the compiler team ship faster, more agile updates every six months, with long-term supported versions every 2 years. For more details, see today‚Äôs blog post on the new MSVC lifecycle.
Insiders and Stable Channels
To support this faster cadence, starting with Visual Studio 2026 two channels are available:
Insiders Channel ‚Äì Try upcoming features first, share feedback, and help shape what is next. To install go to https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/insiders/. (Insiders replaces the ‚ÄúPreview‚Äù Channel previously available.)
Stable Channel ‚Äì Get validated, production-ready features every month. To install, go to https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/downloads/. (Stable replaces the ‚ÄúCurrent‚Äù Channel previously available.)
Features that appear in the Insiders Channel will roll into the Stable Channel when they‚Äôre ready for broad adoption. If you are on Stable, you will receive a monthly feature update and servicing releases as needed. (For more information, see Visual Studio Channels and Release Rhythm and Visual Studio Product Lifecycle and Servicing.)
Each year, the IDE will update to the next annual version, for example next November, Visual Studio 2026 will update in place to Visual Studio 2027, with no disruption to your environment.
Our enterprise customers at times need more flexibility in when they schedule updates. To ensure they are fully supported, we‚Äôll also offer a side-by-side Long-Term-Servicing Channel (LTSC) for the prior annual release. The LTSC provides security servicing for 1 year. For example, in November of 2026, you will be able to choose to switch to the Visual Studio 2026 LTS Channel to remain on a static feature set for an additional year.
However, it‚Äôs important to note that Visual Studio LTSC is not necessary to maintain your project in a known state. If your project uses .NET 10 or MSVC 14.50 that ship with Visual Studio 2026, when you update to Visual Studio 2027 those build tools will still be available, and your projects should just build as before.
Flexible Licensing and Registration
These changes for Visual Studio result in a shift in how we handle product registration. There are no changes to Visual Studio Community, it remains free for open-source projects, education, and small organizations. (See the license for details.)
For the Professional and Enterprise editions, if you have a Visual Studio Subscription, there‚Äôs no change to the registration process. You will continue signing in as before and automatically receive updates through the modern lifecycle or obtain your product key from the Visual Studio Subscribers portal. If you use a stand-alone Professional license, you simply purchase the new annual version each year. Product keys will continue to work for that annual version, and new keys will unlock the next year‚Äôs release.
Additionally, there are no changes to the lifecycle for Visual Studio 2022, Visual Studio 2019, and Visual Studio 2017.
Always Current, Always Ready
Visual Studio 2026 marks the start of a new era, an IDE that is modern, intelligent, and continuously improving. You will spend less time waiting for updates and more time building great software with the latest tools.
We are excited for you to experience this new cadence, share your feedback, and help shape the future of Visual Studio. The journey continues, and Visual Studio will be right there with you, every month, every release.
The post Visual Studio ‚Äì Built for the Speed of Modern Development appeared first on Visual Studio Blog.
posts.dc:creator: Paul Chapman
posts.content:
Visual Studio will adopt the Modern Support Lifecycle as a continuously updated IDE designed to deliver innovation as soon as it is ready, while maintaining the reliability and stability you count on every day with control over your build tools choices.

The post Visual Studio ‚Äì Built for the Speed of Modern Development appeared first on Visual Studio Blog.

Ïò§Îäò, Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî ÏµúÍ∑º Ï∂úÏãúÎêú AI Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÎì§Ïùò Î∂àÌé∏Ìïú ÏßÑÏã§ÏùÑ ÌååÌó§Ï≥êÎ≥¥Í≥†, ÌòÑÏû¨Ïùò Í∏∞Ïà†Ïù¥ Ïñ¥ÎîîÍπåÏßÄ ÏôÄ ÏûàÎäîÏßÄ ÏÜîÏßÅÌïòÍ≤å Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï¥Î≥¥Î†§ Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. ÏßÄÍ∏à Î∞îÎ°ú AI Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÏùò ÎØºÎÇØÏùÑ Ìï®Íªò Îì§Ïó¨Îã§Î≥¥ÏãúÏ£†.

ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ Ï£ºÏûÖ Í≥µÍ≤©: AI Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÏùò ÏïÑÌÇ¨Î†àÏä§Í±¥

ÏöîÏ¶ò LLM(Í±∞ÎåÄ Ïñ∏Ïñ¥ Î™®Îç∏) Ïó¥ÌíçÍ≥º Ìï®Íªò 'AI Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†Ä'ÎùºÎäî ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Ìä∏Î†åÎìúÍ∞Ä ÏÉùÍ≤®ÎÇ¨ÏäµÎãàÎã§. OpenAIÎÇò Perplexity Í∞ôÏùÄ Í±∞Î¨ºÎì§ÎèÑ Íµ¨Í∏Ä ÌÅ¨Î°¨Ïù¥ÎùºÎäî Ï†àÎåÄ Í∞ïÏûêÏóê ÎèÑÏ†ÑÏû•ÏùÑ ÎÇ¥Î∞ÄÏóàÏ£†. ÎèÖÏ†ê Ï≤¥Ï†úÏóê Í≤ΩÏüÅÏù¥ ÏÉùÍ∏∞Îäî Í±¥ Ïñ∏Ï†úÎÇò ÌôòÏòÅÌï† ÏùºÏù¥ÏßÄÎßå, ÏÜîÏßÅÌûà ÎßêÌï¥ÏÑú Ïù¥ ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ AI Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÎì§ÏùÄ ÏïÑÏßÅ 'Ï§ÄÎπÑÍ∞Ä Ïïà ÎêêÎã§'Îäî ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏù¥ Îì§Ïñ¥Ïöî. Ï†ÄÎäî Ìïú Ï£º Ï†ïÎèÑ ChatGPT Atlas Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÎ•º ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï¥Î≥¥Îã§Í∞Ä Í≤∞Íµ≠ ÏÇ≠Ï†úÌïòÍ≥† ÎßêÏïòÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥ Í≤ΩÌóòÏù¥ Ïù¥ Î∂ÑÏïºÎ•º Îçî ÍπäÏù¥ Îì§Ïó¨Îã§Î≥¥Í≤å Îêú Í≥ÑÍ∏∞Í∞Ä ÎêòÏóàÏ£†. ÌååÍ≥†Îì§ÏàòÎ°ù Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÏóâÎö±Ìïú Î∞©Ìñ•ÏúºÎ°ú Í∞ÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî Í±¥ ÏïÑÎãåÍ∞Ä ÌïòÎäî Î∂àÏïàÍ∞êÏù¥ Ïª§Ï°åÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ Î¨∏Ï†ú Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÎäî Î∞îÎ°ú ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ Ï£ºÏûÖ Í≥µÍ≤©(Prompt Injection Attack)Ïóê Ï∑®ÏïΩÌïòÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏù¥ÏóêÏöî. Ïù¥Í≤å Î≠êÎÉêÎ©¥, ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Í∞Ä Ïà®Í≤®ÏßÑ Î™ÖÎ†πÏñ¥Î•º Ïä¨Ï©ç Ïã¨Ïñ¥ ÎÜìÏúºÎ©¥ AIÍ∞Ä ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÏùò ÏßÄÏãú ÎåÄÏã† Í∑∏ Ïà®Í≤®ÏßÑ Î™ÖÎ†πÏñ¥Î•º Îî∞Î•¥Í≤å ÎêòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÎßêÌï©ÎãàÎã§. A3: ÌòÑÏû¨Î°úÏÑúÎäî AI ÏóêÏù¥Ï†ÑÌä∏ Í∏∞Îä•Ïù¥ Í∏∞ÎåÄÎßåÌÅº Ìö®Ïú®Ï†ÅÏù¥ÏßÄ ÏïäÎã§Îäî ÌèâÍ∞ÄÍ∞Ä ÎßéÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏóâÎö±Ìïú ÎèôÏûëÏùÑ ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò ÏÜçÎèÑÍ∞Ä ÎäêÎ¶∞ Í≤ΩÏö∞Í∞Ä ÎßéÏúºÎ©∞, ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ Ï£ºÏûÖ Í≥µÍ≤©Ïóê Ï∑®ÏïΩÌïòÏó¨ ÌîºÏã± Îì± Ïã¨Í∞ÅÌïú Î≥¥Ïïà ÏúÑÌóòÏóê ÎÖ∏Ï∂úÎê† Í∞ÄÎä•ÏÑ±ÎèÑ ÏûàÏñ¥ Ïã§ÏßàÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î¨∏Ï†ú Ìï¥Í≤∞Î≥¥Îã§Îäî ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ ÏúÑÌóòÏùÑ Ï¥àÎûòÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.
Q4: AI Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†Ä ÎåÄÏã† Í∏∞Ï°¥ Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÏôÄ ÌôïÏû• ÌîÑÎ°úÍ∑∏Îû®ÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Îçî ÎÇòÏùÄ ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏùºÍπåÏöî?
A4: ÎÑ§, ÎßéÏùÄ AI Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÏùò ÌïµÏã¨ Í∏∞Îä•Îì§ÏùÄ ÌÅ¨Î°úÎØ∏ÏõÄ Í∏∞Î∞ò Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÏóê AI Í¥ÄÎ†® ÌôïÏû• ÌîÑÎ°úÍ∑∏Îû®ÏùÑ ÏÑ§ÏπòÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÎßåÏúºÎ°úÎèÑ Ï∂©Î∂ÑÌûà Íµ¨ÌòÑ Í∞ÄÎä•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. AIÏùò 'ÏßÄÎä•'Ïù¥ ÌÅ¥ÎùºÏö∞Îìú Í∏∞Î∞òÏù¥ÎùºÎäî Ï†êÏùÑ Í≥†Î†§Ìï† Îïå, Íµ≥Ïù¥ ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ AI Î∏åÎùºÏö∞Ï†ÄÎ•º ÏÑ§ÏπòÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ïû†Ïû¨Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î≥¥Ïïà ÏúÑÌóòÏù¥ÎÇò ÏÑ±Îä• Ï†ÄÌïòÎ•º Í∞êÏàòÌï† ÌïÑÏöîÍ∞Ä ÏóÜÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

posts.title: ÏΩîÎî© ÏóÜÏù¥ 5Î∂Ñ ÎßåÏóê Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞ÄÍ∏â ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏? AI ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ ÏïÑÌÇ§ÌÖçÌä∏Í∞Ä Îãµ!
posts.author: Ïñ¥Îñ§Ïò§ÌõÑÏùò ÌîÑÎ¶¨Ïõ®Ïñ¥ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞
posts.content:
Î≥µÏû°Ìïú ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏ Í∏∞ÌöçÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏΩîÎî©, Î∞∞Ìè¨ÍπåÏßÄ Îã® 5Î∂Ñ ÎßåÏóê ÎÅùÎÇº Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Î©¥ Ïñ¥Îñ†ÏÑ∏Ïöî? 2025ÎÖÑ, AI Í∏∞Ïà†Ïùò Î∞úÏ†ÑÏùÄ Îçî Ïù¥ÏÉÅ ÍøàÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãôÎãàÎã§. ÎπÑÍ∞úÎ∞úÏûêÎèÑ Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞ÄÍ∏â ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÎ•º ÎßåÎì§Í≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎì§ÏùÑ ÏúÑÌï¥, AI ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ ÏïÑÌÇ§ÌÖçÌä∏Í∞Ä Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ïù¥ Î™®Îì† Í≥ºÏ†ïÏùÑ ÌòÅÏã†ÌïòÎäîÏßÄ ÏûêÏÑ∏Ìûà ÏïåÏïÑÎ≥¥Í≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Ï†ú Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùò ÏÉÅÏÉÅÏù¥ ÌòÑÏã§Ïù¥ ÎêòÎäî ÏãúÎåÄÍ∞Ä ÎèÑÎûòÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Ïôú ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÍ∞Ä ÌïÑÏöîÌï†ÍπåÏöî?

Ïùå, ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥ Î≥¥Î©¥ ÎßéÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Í±∞Ï∞ΩÌïú Ïõπ Ïï†ÌîåÎ¶¨ÏºÄÏù¥ÏÖòÎ≥¥Îã§Îäî ÏûêÏã†ÏùÑ ÏÜåÍ∞úÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò ÌäπÏ†ï ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Î•º ÌôçÎ≥¥Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Í∞ÑÎã®ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑúÎèÑ Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ ÌïòÎÇòÎ•º Îçî ÌïÑÏöîÎ°ú ÌïòÏãúÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÏïÑÏöî. ÌäπÌûà Í∞úÎ∞ú Ï∑®ÏóÖÏùÑ Ï§ÄÎπÑ Ï§ëÏù∏ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ÎÇò, Í∞úÏù∏ ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÏãúÏûëÌïòÎ†§Îäî Î∂ÑÎì§ÏóêÍ≤åÎäî Î™ÖÌï®Ï≤òÎüº ÎÇ¥Î∞Ä Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ìè¨Ìä∏Ìè¥Î¶¨Ïò§ ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏ÎÇò ÌöåÏÇ¨ ÌôçÎ≥¥ ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÍ∞Ä Ï†ïÎßê ÌïÑÏàòÏ†ÅÏù¥Ï£†.

Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ ÎßâÏÉÅ ÎßåÎì§Î†§Í≥† ÌïòÎ©¥ Ïñ¥ÎîîÏÑúÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏãúÏûëÌï¥Ïïº Ìï†ÏßÄ ÎßâÎßâÌï† ÎïåÍ∞Ä ÎßéÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏΩîÎî© ÏßÄÏãùÏù¥ ÏóÜÏñ¥ÏÑú Î™ª ÎßåÎìúÎäî Í≤ÉÎ≥¥Îã§, ÏÇ¨Ïã§ÏùÄ 'Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ Îã¥ÏïÑÏïº Ìï†Íπå?', 'ÎîîÏûêÏù∏ÏùÄ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ìï¥Ïïº Ï¥åÏä§ÎüΩÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÑÍπå?' Í∞ôÏùÄ Í∏∞Ìöç Îã®Í≥ÑÏóêÏÑúÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ï¢åÏ†àÌïòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞Í∞Ä ÌÉúÎ∞òÏù¥ÏóêÏöî. Ï†ÄÎèÑ Ï£ºÎ≥ÄÏóêÏÑú Í∑∏Îü∞ Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõÄÏùÑ ÏûêÏ£º Ï†ëÌïòÍ≥§ ÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

'ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ Î©îÏù¥Ïª§' Ï†¨ ÏßÄÏπ®Ïùò ÌÉÑÏÉùÍ≥º ÌïúÍ≥Ñ

Ïù¥Îü∞ Î¨∏Ï†úÎ•º Ìï¥Í≤∞ÌïòÍ≥†Ïûê Ï†úÍ∞Ä Ï≤òÏùå ÏãúÎèÑÌñàÎçò Í≤ÉÏù¥ Î∞îÎ°ú 'ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ Î©îÏù¥Ïª§' Ï†¨(GEM) ÏßÄÏπ®ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ ÏßÄÏπ®ÏùÄ AIÏóêÍ≤å ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ Ï†úÏûëÏóê ÌïÑÏöîÌïú Î™®Îì† Îã®Í≥ÑÎ•º ÏïÑÏ£º Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏïåÎ†§Ï£ºÎäî Îß§Îâ¥ÏñºÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏ£†. ÌÅ¨Í≤å ÏÑ∏ Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏúºÎ°ú ÎÇòÎâ©ÎãàÎã§.

  • Role (Ïó≠Ìï†): AIÏóêÍ≤å Íµ¨Í∏ÄÏùò ÏàòÏÑù UX/UI ÎîîÏûêÏù¥ÎÑàÏù¥Ïûê Ï†ÑÎ¨∏ Ïπ¥ÌîºÎùºÏù¥ÌÑ∞ÎùºÎäî Ï†ïÏ≤¥ÏÑ±ÏùÑ Î∂ÄÏó¨Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Îã®ÏàúÌûà Íµ¨Ï°∞Îßå ÏÑ§Í≥ÑÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ ÎÑòÏñ¥, ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÏùò Ïã¨Î¶¨Î•º Íø∞Îö´Îäî Îß§Î†•Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î¨∏Íµ¨ÏôÄ Ïã§Ï†ú Í∞úÎ∞ú Í∞ÄÎä•Ìïú ÏàòÏ§ÄÏùò ÎîîÌÖåÏùºÌïú Í∏∞ÌöçÎ†•ÏùÑ Í∞ñÏ∂îÎèÑÎ°ù Î™ÖÏãúÌñàÏ£†.
  • Context (Îß•ÎùΩ): ÏµúÏ¢Ö Î™©ÌëúÎ•º 'Î©îÏù∏ ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÏôÄ 4Í∞úÏùò ÏÑúÎ∏å ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÍ∞Ä ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïòÍ≤å Ïó∞Í≤∞Îêú Í≥†ÌíàÏßà ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏ Ï†úÏûë'ÏúºÎ°ú ÏÑ§Ï†ïÌïòÍ≥†, ÏõπÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏ Ï£ºÏ†ú, ÌÉÄÍ≤ü Í≥†Í∞ù, ÌïµÏã¨ Î™©ÌëúÎ•º ÏûÖÎ†•Î∞õÎèÑÎ°ù ÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§.
  • Task & Process (ÏûëÏóÖ Ï†àÏ∞®): Ïù¥ Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏù¥ ÌïµÏã¨Ïù∏Îç∞Ïöî. Ï¥ù 3Îã®Í≥ÑÎ°ú Íµ¨ÏÑ±Îê©ÎãàÎã§.
    • Ïä§ÌÖù 1. Î∏åÎûúÎìú ÏïÑÏù¥Îç¥Ìã∞Ìã∞: ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Îßµ, Primary Color(Hex CodeÏôÄ ÏÑ†ÌÉù Ïù¥Ïú†), Typography, Mood Board(ÌòïÏö©ÏÇ¨ 3Í∞ÄÏßÄ)Î•º Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏßÄÏãúÌï©ÎãàÎã§.
    • Ïä§ÌÖù 2. Î©îÏù∏ ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ ÏÉÅÏÑ∏ Í∏∞Ìöç: Hero Section (Ìó§ÎìúÎùºÏù∏, ÏÑúÎ∏å ÌÖçÏä§Ìä∏, CTA Î≤ÑÌäº 2Í∞ú), Problem & Solution, Key Features 3Í∞ú, Social ProofÍπåÏßÄ Ïã§Ï†ú Îì§Ïñ¥Í∞à Î¨∏Íµ¨Î•º Î™®Îëê ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.
    • Ïä§ÌÖù 3. ÏÑúÎ∏å ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ 4Ï¢Ö: Í∞Å ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄÏùò Ï†úÎ™©, Î™©Ìëú, Ìó§Îçî Ïπ¥Ìîº, ÌïµÏã¨ Î∞îÎîî ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†, CTAÎ•º ÏÉÅÏÑ∏ÌïòÍ≤å ÏûëÏÑ±ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù ÏßÄÏãúÌï©ÎãàÎã§.

Ïù¥ Ï†¨ ÏßÄÏπ®ÏùÑ ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÎ©¥, 'Ïó¥Î¶∞ ÏûÖ ÏπòÍ≥º ÏùòÏõê ÌôàÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ'Ï≤òÎüº Í∞ÑÎã®Ìïú ÏûÖÎ†•ÎßåÏúºÎ°úÎèÑ Î∏åÎûúÎìú ÏïÑÏù¥Îç¥Ìã∞Ìã∞Î∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏïÑÏ£º Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏù∏ UX/UI Î∞©Î≤ïÎ°†Ïù¥ Ìè¨Ìï®Îêú ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ ÏÉùÏÑ± ÏßÄÏπ®ÏùÑ Î∞îÎ°ú Î∞õÏïÑÎ≥º Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ Ïù¥ Í∏∞ÌöçÏïàÏùÑ Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú Ïã§Ï†ú ÏΩîÎìúÎ•º ÏßúÏÑú ÌîÑÎ°úÌÜ†ÌÉÄÏûÖÏùÑ ÎØ∏Î¶¨ ÌôïÏù∏ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÎèÑ Í∞ÄÎä•ÌñàÏ£†.

‚ö†Ô∏è ÌïòÏßÄÎßå Ï†¨ ÏßÄÏπ®ÏùÄ Ìïú Î≤à Îì±Î°ùÌïòÎ©¥ Ï†úÎØ∏ÎÇòÏù¥ÏóêÏÑú Î∞îÎ°ú ÏÇ¨Ïö© Í∞ÄÎä•ÌïòÍ≥† ÏùëÎãµÎèÑ Îπ†Î•¥Îã§Îäî Ïû•Ï†êÏù¥ ÏûàÏßÄÎßå, ÎïåÎ°úÎäî Ï∂úÎ†•Î¨ºÏùò ÎÇ¥Ïö©Ïù¥ ÎßéÍ±∞ÎÇò Î≥µÏû°Ìï† Îïå Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÏõêÌïòÎäî ÎßåÌÅº ÏùºÍ¥ÄÏÑ± ÏûàÎäî Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ•º Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÎäî ÌïúÍ≥ÑÍ∞Ä ÏûàÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§.
*GEMÏßÄÏπ®ÏõêÎ≥∏ÏùÄ Î≥∏Î¨∏ ÌïòÎã®Ïóê ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§.

2025ÎÖÑÏùò Ìï¥Í≤∞Ï±Ö: AI ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ ÏïÑÌÇ§ÌÖçÌä∏

Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú ÌïúÍ≥ÑÎ•º Í∑πÎ≥µÌïòÍ≥† Îçî ÏùºÍ¥ÄÏÑ± ÏûàÍ≥† Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ¨ºÏùÑ ÏñªÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ Ïï±ÏúºÎ°ú Íµ¨ÌòÑÌïú Í≤ÉÏù¥ Î∞îÎ°ú Ïò§Îäò Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÍªò ÏÜåÍ∞úÌï¥ ÎìúÎ¶¥ 'AI ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ ÏïÑÌÇ§ÌÖçÌä∏'ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. 2025ÎÖÑ ÌòÑÏû¨, Ïù¥ Ïï±ÏùÄ ÎûúÎî©ÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ Ï†úÏûë Í≥ºÏ†ïÏùÑ ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Ï∞®ÏõêÏúºÎ°ú ÎÅåÏñ¥Ïò¨Î†∏Îã§Í≥† ÏûêÏã† ÏûàÍ≤å ÎßêÏîÄÎìúÎ¶¥ Ïàò ÏûàÏñ¥Ïöî. Ïù¥Ï†ú Ïï±ÏùÑ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ìï¥ Î≥¥Îäî Í≥ºÏ†ïÏùÑ Ìï®Íªò ÏÇ¥Ìé¥Î≥¥ÏãúÏ£†.

posts.title: VCÎäî ÎòëÎòëÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïÑÎèÑ ÎêúÎã§
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
2012ÎÖÑÎèÑÏóê Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±ÏùÑ ÏãúÏûëÌñàÏùÑ Îïå, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä VCÎ•º ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÏÑú ÏûòÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑÏßÑ ÌôïÏã†Ïù¥ ÏóÜÏóàÏßÄÎßå, Îëê Í∞ÄÏßÄÎßåÏùÄ ÌôïÏã†Ïù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ïù¥ Îëê Í∞úÏùò ÌôïÏã†ÏùÄ Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±ÏùÑ ÏãúÏûëÌïòÍ≥† 13ÎÖÑÏù¥ ÏßÄÎÇú Ïò§ÎäòÎèÑ Ïö∞Î¶¨ ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò Í∏∞Ï¥àÍ∞Ä ÎêòÎäî Îëê Í∞úÏùò ÌäºÌäºÌïú Í∏∞Îë• Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§.
ÌïòÎÇòÎäî, ÎãπÏãúÏóê ‚Äì Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏßÄÍ∏àÎèÑ ÎßàÏ∞¨Í∞ÄÏßÄÎã§ ‚Äì ÏãúÏû•Ïóê Ï°¥Ïû¨ÌïòÎçò ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò VCÏôÄÎäî Îã§Î•∏ ÏÑ±Ìñ•Í≥º ÏÉâÍπîÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏßÑ Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÍ∞Ä Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Í≥† ÎØøÏóàÎã§. Î¨¥Ïä® ÎßêÏù¥ÎÉê ÌïòÎ©¥, Ï†ïÎßêÎ°ú ÌöåÏÇ¨ÏôÄ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏóêÍ≤å ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî VCÍ∞Ä ÎêòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏóàÎã§. Î™®Îì† VCÍ∞Ä ÌöåÏÇ¨ÏôÄ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏóêÍ≤å ÎèÑÏõÄÏùÑ Ï£ºÎ†§Í≥† ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎÉêÍ≥† Î¨ºÏñ¥Î≥º Ïàò ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Í≤âÏúºÎ°úÎäî Îã§ Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å ÎßêÌïòÍ≥† Ïó∞Í∏∞ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, Ïã§Ï†ú VC ÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥ÑÎ•º Î≥¥Î©¥, Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎ•º ÎÇòÏôÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ Í≥†Í∑ÄÌïú Ïù∏Í≤©Ï≤¥Î°ú Ï°¥Ï§ëÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÏµúÎåÄÌïú ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê ÎèÑÏõÄÏùÑ Ï£ºÎ†§Í≥† ÎÖ∏Î†•ÌïòÎäî VCÍ∞Ä Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å ÎßéÏßÄ ÏïäÎã§. Ïù¥Í±¥ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù¥ÎÇò ÎØ∏Íµ≠Ïù¥ÎÇò ÎßàÏ∞¨Í∞ÄÏßÄÏù∏Îç∞, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Í∞ÄÏû• Ï°¥Í≤ΩÌïòÎäî VC Ï§ë Ìïú Î™ÖÏù∏ ÏΩîÏä¨ÎùºÎ≤§Ï≤òÏä§Ïùò ÎπÑÎÖ∏Îìú ÏΩîÏä¨ÎùºÎèÑ ‚ÄúVCÎì§Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê ÎèÑÏõÄÏùÑ Ï£ºÎäî Í±¥ Î∞îÎùºÏßÄÎèÑ ÏïäÎäîÎã§. Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÏïÑÎ¨¥Í≤ÉÎèÑ Ïïà Ìï¥ÎèÑ Í¥úÏ∞ÆÎã§. VCÎì§Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê Ìï¥Î•º ÎÅºÏπòÍ≥†, ÌöåÏÇ¨Î•º ÎßùÍ∞ÄÎú®Î¶¨ÏßÄÎßå ÏïäÏúºÎ©¥ Ïù¥Îì§ÏùÄ Ï¢ãÏùÄ VCÎã§.‚ÄùÎùºÍ≥† ÎßêÌï† Ï†ïÎèÑÎ°ú ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê ÌîºÌï¥Î•º Ï£ºÍ≥† ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò Î∂ÄÏ±ÑÍ∞Ä ÎêòÎäî VCÎì§Ïù¥ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÎßéÎã§. ÎÇòÎäî Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±Ïù¥ Í∑∏ Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÏÉÅÌô©ÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏùò Ìé∏Ïóê ÏÑúÏÑú Ïù¥Îì§Ïùò Îì†Îì†Ìïú ÏßÄÏõêÍµ∞Ïù¥ ÎêòÎäî VCÍ∞Ä Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî ÌôïÏã†Ïù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎã§.
Îëê Î≤àÏß∏Îäî, ÎòëÎòëÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÄ VCÍ∞Ä Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî ÌôïÏã†Ïù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎã§. Ïù¥Í±¥ Îòê Î¨¥Ïä® Í∞úÏÜåÎ¶¨Ïù∏Í∞Ä ÏùòÏïÑÌï¥ÌïòÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§ÏùÑ ÏúÑÌï¥ Ïû†Íπê ÏÑ§Î™ÖÌïòÎ©¥,,,ÎßéÏùÄ Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Ï≤®Îã® ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏóê Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÍ≥†, Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏóêÍ≤å Ïò®Í∞ñ Ïñ¥Î†§Ïö¥ ÏßàÎ¨∏ÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥ ÌïòÎäî Í±∏ Î≥¥Í≥† VCÎì§Ïù¥ IQÍ∞Ä ÎÜíÍ≥† ÎòëÎòëÌïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÎäîÎç∞, ÏÜîÏßÅÌûà ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎäî ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò VCÎäî ‚Äì Ïù¥Í±¥ ÎÇòÎèÑ Ìè¨Ìï® ‚Äì Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å ÎòëÎòëÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎã§. ÏïÑÎãà, Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ Í∑∏ Î∞òÎåÄÏù¥Îã§. ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎäî ÎßéÏùÄ VCÎäî Ïã§Ï†úÎ°úÎäî Î©çÏ≤≠ÌïúÎç∞, ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ ÏóÑÏ≤≠ ÎòëÎòëÌïú Ï≤ôÌïúÎã§. ÏßÄÍ∏àÎèÑ Í∑∏Î†áÏßÄÎßå, 13ÎÖÑ Ï†ÑÏóêÎèÑ ÎπÑÏä∑ÌñàÎã§. Í∑ºÎç∞ ÎãπÏãú ÎÇ¥ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏùÄ VCÎäî Î≥ÑÎ°ú ÎòëÎòëÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïÑÎèÑ ÎêòÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÎäî Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÄ Î∞òÎìúÏãú ÎòëÎòëÌï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ÏóàÎã§. ÌäπÌûà Ïö∞Î¶¨ Í∞ôÏùÄ Ï¥àÍ∏∞ VCÏùò Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ Îä•Î†•ÏùÄ ÎòëÎòëÌïú Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÑ Îã§Î•∏ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Î≥¥Îã§ Î®ºÏ†Ä ÏïåÏïÑÎ≥¥Í≥†, Ïù¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÍ∞Ä Îã§Î•∏ VCÍ∞Ä ÏïÑÎãå ÎÇ¥ ÎèàÏùÑ Î∞õÍ≤å ÏÑ§ÎìùÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÎÇòÎäî Ïù¥Í±¥ ÏûêÏã† ÏûàÏóàÎã§.
Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±ÏùÑ ÏãúÏûëÌï† Îïå, ÎÇòÎäî ÎèàÎèÑ ÏóÜÏóàÍ≥†, ÎÑ§Ìä∏ÏõåÌÅ¨ÎèÑ ÏóÜÏóàÍ≥†, VCÎùºÎäî ÏóÖÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Ïù¥Ìï¥ÎèÑÎèÑ ÌïúÏ∞∏ Îñ®Ïñ¥Ï°åÏóàÏßÄÎßå, ÏúÑÏóêÏÑú Îßê Ìïú Îëê Í∞ÄÏßÄÏùò Í∏∞Î≥∏ ÏûêÍ≤©Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑúÎäî Í∑∏ ÎàÑÍµ¨Î≥¥Îã§ ÌôïÏã†Ïù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎã§. Í≤∞Íµ≠ ÎÇòÏùò Í∞ÄÏû• ÏÜåÏ§ëÌïú Í≥†Í∞ùÏùÄ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏù¥Îãà Î¨¥Ïä® ÏùºÏù¥ ÏûàÏñ¥ÎèÑ Ïù¥Îì§ÏùÑ Ï°¥Ï§ëÌïòÍ≥† Ïù¥Îì§Ïùò Ìé∏Ïóê ÏÑúÎäî Í≤É, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÎÇòÎäî Î©çÏ≤≠Ìï¥ÎèÑ ÏÉÅÍ¥ÄÏóÜÏúºÎãàÍπå, ÏûêÎßåÏã¨Í≥º ÏûêÏ°¥Ïã¨ Îã§ ÌïÑÏöî ÏóÜÍ≥† Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÎòëÎòëÌïú Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎ•º Î®ºÏ†Ä ÏïåÏïÑÎ≥¥Í≥† Ïù¥Îì§ÏóêÍ≤å Î®ºÏ†Ä Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÎäî Í≤É. Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÏãúÏûëÌï† Îïê Ïù¥Í≤ÉÎ∞ñÏóê ÏóÜÏóàÎã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† 13ÎÖÑÏù¥ ÏßÄÎÇú ÏßÄÍ∏àÎèÑ Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Ïù¥ ÎØøÏùåÍ≥º ÌôïÏã†ÏùÄ Î≥ÄÏπò ÏïäÍ≥† Ïûò ÏßÄÏºúÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Í≥† ÎÇòÎäî ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§.
VCÎäî ÎòëÎòëÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïÑÎèÑ ÎêúÎã§Îäî Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±Ïùò ÎØøÏùåÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ Ï°∞Í∏à Îçî Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï¥ Î≥¥Í≥† Ïã∂Îã§. ÎßåÏïΩÏóê Ïñ¥Îñ§ VCÍ∞Ä Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏôÄ ÎØ∏ÌåÖÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Í∑∏ ÌöåÏùòÏã§ÏóêÏÑú Í∑∏Í∞Ä Í∞ÄÏû• ÎòëÎòëÌïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥ÎùºÎ©¥, ÎòêÎäî Í∞ÄÏû• ÎòëÎòëÌïòÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÍ≥† ÏûêÎßåÌïúÎã§Î©¥, Í∑∏Îäî Î∞©ÏùÑ Ïûò Î™ª Ï∞æÏïÑÏò® Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. ÏôúÎÉêÌïòÎ©¥ Ïù¥Îü∞ Í≤ΩÏö∞, Ìà¨Ïûê Í≤ÄÌÜ†Î•º ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ÎèÑÏõÄÏù¥ ÎêòÎäî Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏñªÏùÑ Ïàò ÏóÜÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÎòëÎòëÌïú Ï≤ôÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÍ∞Ä ÎßêÌïòÎäî Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Î∞òÎ∞ïÌïòÎäî VCÎì§ ÏïûÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÍ∞Ä Ï£ºÎàÖÏù¥ Îì§Í≥†, ÏßúÏ¶ù ÎÇòÏÑú Ïù¥Îì§Í≥º Ï†úÎåÄÎèÑ Îêú ÎåÄÌôîÎ•º Ìï† Ïàò ÏóÜÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. 
Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ ÎÖ∏Î†®Ìïú VCÎì§ÏùÄ Ï†àÎåÄÎ°ú ÌöåÏùòÏã§ÏóêÏÑú Í∞ÄÏû• ÎòëÎòëÌïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÏù¥ ÎêòÎ†§Í≥† ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäîÎã§. ÏúÑÏóêÏÑú ÎßêÌïú ÎåÄÎ°ú Ïù¥Îü∞ Î∂ÑÏúÑÍ∏∞Í∞Ä Ï°∞ÏÑ±ÎêòÎ©¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥ ÏûêÏã†Ïùò ÎßàÏùåÏùÑ Ïó¥ÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥†, Í∑∏Îü¨Î©¥ Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÎì§Ïù¥ Ï†ïÎßêÎ°ú ÏïåÍ≥† Ïã∂Ïñ¥ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ ÏïåÎ†§ Ï£ºÏßÄ ÏïäÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Î≥¥Îã§ Î≥∏Ïù∏Îì§Ïù¥ ÎòëÎòëÌïòÍ≥†, Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Î≥∏Ïù∏Îì§Ïù¥ Îçî Ïûò ÏïàÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÎ©¥, ÏßÅÏ†ë ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ Ìï¥Î≥¥Î©¥ ÎêúÎã§. Î¨ºÎ°†, Í∑∏Îü¥ Ïö©Í∏∞Îäî ÏóÜÏùÑ Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.

ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≤å ÌïúÍµ≠Í≥º ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖ ÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥Ñ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º ÌäπÌûà ÎßéÏù¥ ÌñàÎäîÎç∞, ÌïúÍµ≠Ïóê ÏßëÏ§ëÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÎäî ÎÇò Í∞ôÏùÄ VCÎäî ÎãπÏó∞Ìûà ÏùºÎ≥∏ ÏãúÏû•Î≥¥Îã® ÌïúÍµ≠ Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖ ÏãúÏû•Ïù¥ Îçî Ï¢ãÎã§Í≥† ÎØøÏßÄÎßå, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎßåÎÇú ÏùºÎ≥∏ VCÎì§ÎèÑ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Î≤§Ï≤òÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥ÑÎ•º Î∂ÄÎü¨ÏõåÌïòÎäî ÎäêÎÇåÏùÑ Í∞ïÌïòÍ≤å Î∞õÏïòÎã§. Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÏùºÎ≥∏ VCÎäî ÎåÄÎÜìÍ≥† ÎÇòÏóêÍ≤å ÌïúÍµ≠ Î≤§Ï≤òÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥ÑÎ•º Î≥º ÎïåÎßàÎã§ ÎÑàÎ¨¥ÎÇò Î∂ÄÎüΩÍ≥†, ÏùºÎ≥∏ÎèÑ ÌïúÍµ≠ ÏãúÏû•Í≥º Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Î°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ AÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ZÍπåÏßÄ Î™®Îì† Í±∏ Ï†ÅÍ∑πÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î∞∞ÏõåÏïº ÌïúÎã§Í≥† Ï£ºÏû•ÌñàÎã§.
ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò ÏÉÅÏû• ÏãúÏû•Ïùò ÌÅ¨Í∏∞Îäî ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò 3.5Î∞∞ Ï†ïÎèÑÍ∞Ä ÎêúÎã§. ÏÉÅÎãπÌûà ÌÅ¨Í≥†, ÎÇú ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù¥ Ï°∞ÎßåÍ∞Ñ ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò ÏÉÅÏû• ÏãúÏû• Í∑úÎ™®Î•º Îõ∞Ïñ¥ÎÑòÏùÑ Í≤ÉÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÌôïÏã†ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ÌòÑÏû¨Ïùò Ïù¥ Í∑úÎ™®Îäî ÏÉÅÎãπÌûà Î∂ÄÎüΩÎã§. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎßåÎÇú ÏùºÎ≥∏ VCÎì§ÏùÄ Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Ïó≠ÎèôÏ†ÅÏù¥Í≥† ÌÅ∞ IPO ÏãúÏû•Ïù¥ Î∂ÄÎüΩÎã§Í≥† Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÌñàÎã§. Î¨¥Ïä® ÎßêÏù∏ÏßÄ Îçî Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Î¨ºÏñ¥Î≥¥Îãà, ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò ÏÉÅÏû• ÏãúÏû•ÏùÄ ÌÅ¨ÏßÄÎßå, ÏûêÏÑ∏Ìûà Î≥¥Î©¥ tech IPOÎäî ÏßàÎ≥¥Îã® ÏñëÏúºÎ°ú ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Îäî Í≤å Ïù¥Îì§Ïùò ÎãµÎ≥ÄÏù¥Îã§. ÌïúÍµ≠ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÄ ÍøàÍ≥º ÏïºÎßùÏù¥ ÏÉÅÎåÄÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ïª§ÏÑú Ìï≠ÏÉÅ ÏïÑÏ£º ÌÅ∞ IPOÎ•º ÍøàÍæ∏Î©¥ÏÑú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌïòÎäîÎç∞ ‚Äì Î¨ºÎ°†, Í∑∏Î†áÎã§Í≥† IPOÎ•º Îã§ ÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÎèÑ ÏïÑÎãàÍ≥†, Ìï¥ÎèÑ ÌÅ∞ IPOÍ∞Ä ÎêòÎäî Í±¥ ÏïÑÎãàÏßÄÎßå ‚Äì ÏùºÎ≥∏ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÌïòÎã§Í∞Ä Ïñ¥Îäê ÏãúÏ†êÏóê Í∑∏ÎÉ• ÏûëÏùÄ IPOÎ•º ÌïòÎäî Í≤å ÏöîÏÉå Ïú†ÌñâÍ∞ôÏù¥ Î≤àÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Í≥† ÌñàÎã§. Ìïú 1,000Ïñµ Ï†ïÎèÑÏùò IPOÎ•º ÌïòÎ©¥ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÄ Í∑∏ÎûòÎèÑ Ïûò Î®πÍ≥† ÏûòÏÇ¥ Ïàò ÏûàÍ≥†, ÏùºÎ≥∏ÏóêÏÑú Ïù¥Îü∞ ÏûëÏùÄ IPOÎ•º ÌïòÎäî Í≤å ÏÉÅÎåÄÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏâΩÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÎÑàÎèÑÎÇòÎèÑ Ï†ÅÎãπÌïú Í∑úÎ™®Î°ú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÌÇ§Ïö∞Í≥† IPOÎ•º ÌïúÎã§Í≥† Îì§ÏóàÎã§. Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÄ ÎèàÏùÑ Î≤åÏñ¥ÏÑú Ï¢ãÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê Ìà¨ÏûêÌïú VCÎäî ÌÅ∞ Ïû¨ÎØ∏Î•º Î™ª Î≥¥Í≥†, Í≥ÑÏÜç Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïùò ÍøàÍ≥º ÏïºÎßùÏù¥ Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ï§ÑÏñ¥Îì§Î©¥ ÏùºÎ≥∏ Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖ ÏÉùÌÉúÍ≥ÑÎäî ÌÅ∞ ÏÑ±Ïû•ÏùÑ Ìï† Ïàò ÏóÜÎã§Îäî Ïö∞Î†§Î•º ÎåÄÌôî ÎÇ¥ÎÇ¥ ÌëúÏãúÌñàÎã§. Ï†ïÌôïÌïòÍ≤å ‚ÄúÏûëÏùÄ IPOÍ∞Ä ÌïòÎÇòÏî© Îê† ÎïåÎßàÎã§ ÏùºÎ≥∏ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïùò ÏïºÎßùÎèÑ ÌïòÎÇòÏî© Ï§ÑÏñ¥ÎìúÎäî Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§.‚ÄùÎùºÎäî ÎßêÏùÑ ÌñàÎäîÎç∞, Í≥∞Í≥∞Ïù¥ ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥ Î≥¥Î©¥ ÏùºÎ¶¨Í∞Ä ÏûàÎäî Îßê Í∞ôÎã§.
Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏùºÎ≥∏ VCÎì§Î°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Î∞òÎ≥µÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Îì§ÏóàÎçò Ï£ºÏ†úÏù¥Ïûê, Ïù¥Îì§Ïù¥ ÌïúÍµ≠Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Í∞ÄÏû• Î∂ÄÎü¨ÏõåÌïòÎäî Í≤å ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏Îì§Ïùò ‚ÄúÏÜåÎπÑÏûê DNA(Consumer DNA)‚ÄùÏòÄÎã§. ÌïúÍµ≠ ÏãúÏû•Ïóî ÏÜåÎπÑÏûê DNAÍ∞Ä Îß§Ïö∞ Í∞ïÌïòÍ≤å ÏûêÎ¶¨ Ïû°Í≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥Îäî Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤Ñ, Ïø†Ìå°, Ïπ¥Ïπ¥Ïò§, ÌÜ†Ïä§, ÎãπÍ∑º, Î∞∞Îã¨Ïùò ÎØºÏ°± Îì±Í≥º Í∞ôÏùÄ Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÏûêÏ≤¥ B2C Ïú†ÎãàÏΩòÏùÑ ÎÅäÏûÑÏóÜÏù¥ ÎßåÎì§Í≥† Ï†úÌíàÌôîÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ïù¥Ïú†Îã§. Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Í≥ÑÏÜç Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÏÜåÎπÑÏûê Ï†úÌíàÎì§Ïù¥ ÏãúÏû•Ïóê Ï∂úÏãúÎêòÎ©¥, ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏ ÌäπÏú†Ïùò Í≤ΩÏüÅÏã¨Í≥º ÏßàÌà¨Í∞Ä Î∞úÎèôÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú Í≥ÑÏÜç Îçî Ï¢ãÏùÄ Í∏∞Îä•, Îçî Ï¢ãÏùÄ UI/UX, Îçî Ï¢ãÏùÄ Í∞ÄÍ≤©Ïùò Í≤ΩÏüÅ Ï†úÌíàÎì§Ïù¥ ÎÇòÏò§Î©¥ÏÑú ‚ÄúÏñëÏù¥ ÏßàÏùÑ ÎßåÎìúÎäî‚Äù Ìö®Í≥ºÍ∞Ä Í∑πÎåÄÌôîÎêúÎã§.
ÏùºÎ≥∏ÏùÄ Ïù¥ ÏÜåÎπÑÏûê DNAÍ∞Ä Ï†êÏ†ê Îçî ÏÇ¨ÎùºÏ†∏ÏÑú Ïù¥Ï†† Í±∞Ïùò ÏóÜÎã§Îäî Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º Îì§ÏóàÎã§. ÏùºÎ≥∏ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÄ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ B2BÏóêÎßå ÏßëÏ§ëÌïòÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÏùºÎ≥∏ÏùÑ ÎåÄÌëúÌïòÎäî ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò B2C Ï†úÌíàÏù¥ ÌïúÍµ≠Í≥º Í∞ôÏù¥ ÎßéÏßÄÎèÑ ÏïäÍ≥† Îã§ÏñëÌïòÏßÄÎèÑ ÏïäÎã§. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, Ïù∏Íµ¨ÎèÑ ÎßéÍ≥† ÏãúÏû•Ïù¥ ÌÅ¨Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò ÏÜåÎπÑÏûê ÏãúÏû•ÏùÄ Ïô∏Íµ≠ ÌöåÏÇ¨Îì§Ïùò ÎÜÄÏù¥ÌÑ∞Í∞Ä ÎêêÎã§. Í≤ÄÏÉâÏùÄ Íµ¨Í∏Ä, ÎèôÏòÅÏÉÅÏùÄ Ïú†ÌäúÎ∏å, ÏßÄÎèÑÎäî Íµ¨Í∏ÄÎßµÏä§, Ïù¥Ïª§Î®∏Ïä§Îäî ÏïÑÎßàÏ°¥, ÌÉùÏãú Ìò∏Ï∂úÏùÄ Ïö∞Î≤Ñ Îì±, ÏùºÎ≥∏ÏùÑ ÏßÄÎ∞∞ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùò B2C Ï†úÌíàÏùÄ Ïô∏ÏÇ∞ Ï†úÌíàÎì§Ïù¥Îã§. Í∑∏Îü¨Î©¥ÏÑú ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Îì§ÏóàÎçò ÎßêÏùÄ ÏùºÎ≥∏ÏùÄ Ï†Ñ ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÏóêÏÑú Ïô∏Íµ≠ B2C ÏÜåÌîÑÌä∏Ïõ®Ïñ¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Îì§Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÏû• ÏâΩÍ≤å ÏßÑÏ∂úÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî, Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ ÏãúÏû•Ïù¥ Îê† Í≤ÉÏù¥Í≥†ÎêêÍ≥†, Ïù¥Îì§ÏùÄ ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò ÏÜåÎπÑÏûê DNAÍ∞Ä ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà ÏÇ¨ÎùºÏßÄÎäî Í≤ÉÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Í±±Ï†ïÍ≥º ÏïÑÏâ¨ÏõÄÏùÑ ÎßéÏù¥ ÌëúÏãúÌñàÎã§.
Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÌïúÍµ≠ÏùÄ Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏÑú Î©àÏ∂îÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† Í≥ÑÏÜç ÏßÑÌôîÌïòÍ≥† Î∞úÏ†ÑÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨ÎßåÏùò ÏÜåÎπÑÏûê DNAÎ•º Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú ÏºÄÏù¥Ìåù, ÏºÄÏù¥Ìë∏Îìú, ÏºÄÏù¥Î∑∞Ìã∞, ÏºÄÏù¥ÏΩòÌÖêÏ∏†ÏôÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Î¨¥ÌòïÏùò ÏÜåÎπÑÏûê DNAÍ∞Ä ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÍ≥†, Ïù¥ Î¨¥ÌòïÏùò ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Î¨∏ÌôîÍ∞Ä ÌòÑÏû¨ ÏùºÎ≥∏ ÏãúÏû•ÏùÑ ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà Ïì∞ÎÇòÎØ∏Í∞ôÏù¥ ÎçÆÏπòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. Ïã§ÏùÄ ÏùºÎ≥∏ÎèÑ Ìïú ÎïåÎäî Îã§Î•∏ ÎÇòÎùºÏùò Î¨∏ÌôîÏóê ÌÅ∞ ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ ÎØ∏Ï≥§ÎäîÎç∞, ÏßÄÍ∏àÏùÄ Ïù¥Í≤å Îã§ Ï£ΩÏóàÍ≥†, Ïò§ÌûàÎ†§ ÌïúÍµ≠ Î¨∏ÌôîÍ∞Ä Í≥ºÍ±∞ ÏùºÎ≥∏ Î¨∏ÌôîÎ≥¥Îã§ Îçî Ïª§ÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Ïù¥Í≤å Î™®Îëê Îã§ ÏùºÎ≥∏Ïùò ÏÜåÎπÑÏûê DNAÏùò ÏÜåÎ©∏Î°ú Ïù∏Ìïú ÏïÑÏ£º Ï¢ãÏßÄ ÏïäÏùÄ Í≤∞Í≥ºÎùºÎäî Í≤∞Î°†ÏùÑ Ïù¥Î∂ÑÏùÄ ÎÇ¥Î†∏Îã§.
Î¨ºÎ°†, ÌïúÎëê Î™ÖÏùò ÏùºÎ≥∏ VCÍ∞Ä ÏùºÎ≥∏Í≥º ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò ÏãúÏû•ÏùÑ ÏïÑÏ£º Ï†ïÌôïÌïòÍ≤å ÌååÏïÖÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÎèÑ ÏïÑÎãàÍ≥†, ÏãúÏû• ÌòÑÌô©ÏùÑ ÏùºÎ∞òÌôîÌï† ÏàòÎèÑ ÏóÜÏßÄÎßå, 10ÎÖÑ ÎÑòÍ≤å ÏùºÎ≥∏ÏóêÏÑú Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî VCÎì§ÏóêÍ≤å Ïù¥ÎÇ† ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Îì§ÏóàÎçò ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÎßåÏùÑ Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú Í≤∞Î°†ÏùÑ ÎÇ¥Î†§Î≥¥Î©¥, B2C Î∂ÑÏïºÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÌïúÍµ≠ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥ ÏùºÎ≥∏ ÏãúÏû•ÏùÑ Ï†ëÏàòÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÏûòÌïòÎäî B2CÎ°ú ÏãúÏûëÌïòÏßÄÎßå, ÎÇ®ÏóêÍ≤å ÏßÄÎäî Í±∏ Î∞∞ ÏïÑÌååÌïòÎäî ÌïúÍµ≠Ïù∏ ÌäπÏú†Ïùò Í≤ΩÏüÅÏã¨Í≥º ÏßàÌà¨Ïã¨ÏúºÎ°ú Í≤∞Íµ≠Ïóî B2B ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÎèÑ ÏùºÎ≥∏ ÏãúÏû•ÏóêÏÑú Îçî ÏûòÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑÍ±∞Îùº ÎØøÎäîÎã§. Ï†ïÎßêÎ°ú Îçî ÎßéÏùÄ ÌïúÍµ≠ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥ ÏùºÎ≥∏ ÏãúÏû•Ïóê ÏßÑÏ∂úÌï¥ÏÑú Í±∞ÎåÄÌïú ÏÇ¨ÏóÖÏùÑ ÎßåÎì§ Ïàò ÏûàÍ∏∏ Î∞îÎûÄÎã§.
ÎßàÏßÄÎßâÏúºÎ°ú,,,ÎÇ¥ ÏπúÍµ¨Ïù¥Ïûê VCÏù∏ ÏùºÎ≥∏ Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÍ∞Ä ÌïúÍµ≠ ÏãúÏû•Ïù¥ Î∂ÄÎüΩÎã§Í≥† ÌïòÎäî Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ Ïù¥Ïú†Îäî Í≤∞Íµ≠Ïóî Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥Îã§. Ìïú Í≥® Î®πÏúºÎ©¥ Îëê Í≥®ÏùÑ ÎÑ£Ïñ¥ÏïºÏßÄ ÏßÅÏÑ±Ïù¥ ÌíÄÎ¶¨Îäî Ïö∞Î¶¨ ÌäπÏú†Ïùò ÏÑ±Íπî?, Ï†àÎåÄÎ°ú Ï£ΩÏßÄ ÏïäÍ≥† ÏÉùÏ°¥ÌïòÎäî Î∞îÌÄ¥Î≤åÎ†àÎ†•, Ïù¥ Î™®Îì† Í≤å ÌïúÍµ≠Ïùò Í∞ïÏ†êÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§. ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ï†ÑÏóê Ïó¨Îü¨ Î≤à Ìè¨Ïä§ÌåÖ ÌñàÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥ Í∞ïÏ†êÏùÑ Ïö∞Î¶∞ Í≥ÑÏÜç ÏÇ¥Î†§Ïïº ÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥ Í∞ïÏ†êÏùÑ ÏÇ¥Î¶¨Í∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑúÎäî Îçî ÏπòÏó¥ÌïòÍ≤å, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ïó¥Ïã¨Ìûà ÏùºÌï¥Ïïº ÌïúÎã§.

ÏûëÌíàÏùÄ Ï†ÑÏüÅÍ≥º ÏÇ¨Í≥†, Ïû¨ÎÇúÏù¥ Îí§ÏÑûÏù∏ Ïñ¥ÏàòÏÑ†Ìïú ÏÑ∏ÏÉÅÏóêÏÑú ÏãúÏûëÌï¥ Îã§ÏñëÌïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ Ìï®Íªò ÏÇ¥ÏïÑÍ∞ÄÎäî ÌèâÌôîÎ°úÏö¥ ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ°ú Ìñ•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. Í∑∏ Î≥ÄÌôîÎ•º ÏßßÏßÄÎßå Í∞ïÎ†¨Ìïú Ïù¥ÎØ∏ÏßÄÎ°ú ÌëúÌòÑÌïòÍ≥†Ïûê ÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§.
Ïó¨Îü¨ ÏïÑÌã∞Ïä§Ìä∏ÏôÄ Ìï®Íªò ÏΩúÎùºÎ≥¥Ìï† Í∏∞ÌöåÎäî ÌùîÏπò ÏïäÏùÄÎç∞, Ï¶êÍ≤ÅÍ≥† ÏùòÎØ∏ ÏûàÎäî ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ÏóàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ ÏòÅÏÉÅÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïã† Î∂ÑÎì§Ïù¥ Ïû†ÏãúÎùºÎèÑ Ï¢ãÏùÄ Í∏∞Î∂ÑÏùÑ ÎäêÎÅºÏã†Îã§Î©¥ Ï†ÄÎèÑ ÌñâÎ≥µÌï† Í≤É Í∞ôÏäµÎãàÎã§. Îî∞ÎúªÌïòÍ≥† Î∞òÏßùÏù¥Îäî Ïó∞Îßê Î≥¥ÎÇ¥ÏãúÍ∏∏ Î∞îÎûçÎãàÎã§.
